title: 109_hr2297
content:
The text chunk "SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS; PURPOSES." is a condensed summary of the section's title, findings, and purposes. The "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Act" recognizes the Arabia Mountain area's natural, cultural, historical, and recreational resources. It emphasizes the importance of partnerships between public and private entities for resource management. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve and Panola Mountain are highlighted for their conservation efforts. The "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Act" recognizes and preserves federally-protected plant species, a national natural landmark at Panola Mountain State Conservation Park, an archaeological site at Miners Creek Preserve, historic granite mining sites in Lithonia, Georgia, and Klondike as a potential National Historic District. Lithonia also has structures listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The Act aims to promote and interpret the natural, cultural, historical, scenic, and recreational resources in the area for public benefit. The Act aims to recognize, preserve, promote, and make available natural, cultural, historical, scenic, and recreational resources in the Arabia Mountain area, including Panola Mountain and Miners Creek. It also assists Georgia and DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties in developing a management program to protect and interpret these resources within the heritage area. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS.

Heritage area - Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area
Management entity - DeKalb County Parks and Recreation Department or successor
Management plan - plan for the heritage area
Secretary - Secretary of the Interior
State - State of Georgia SEC. 3. ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA established in Georgia, consisting of land in DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties. Map available for public inspection. Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance is the management entity. SEC. 4. Authorities and duties of the management entity. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia has the authority to make grants, hire staff, and enter into contracts. They are responsible for developing and submitting a management plan that considers the interests of various groups within the area. Priority is given to actions that assist in preserving resources within the heritage area. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia is responsible for implementing actions outlined in the management plan, including assisting government and nonprofit organizations in resource preservation and encouraging local governments to adopt land use policies consistent with the plan. They must conduct quarterly public meetings on plan implementation, submit an annual report on accomplishments and finances, and make all expenditure records available for audit by the Secretary. The management entity must provide records for audit to the Secretary regarding the expenditure of Federal funds and ensure receiving organizations do the same. Federal funds cannot be used to acquire real property, but funds from other sources can be used for authorized purposes under other Federal laws. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The management entity must develop a plan for the heritage area based on the preferred concept in the feasibility study. The plan should consider state and local plans, involve residents, and include an inventory of resources to be preserved, restored, managed, or maintained. The management plan for the heritage area includes provisions for protection, interpretation, and enjoyment of resources, an interpretation plan, implementation program, and evaluation of the management entity. The management plan for the heritage area must include identification of funding sources, evaluation of the management entity, and submission to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of enactment. The Secretary will approve or disapprove the plan within 90 days of submission. Approval or disapproval of the management plan must be done by the Secretary within 90 days of submission. If the plan is disapproved, the Secretary will provide reasons and allow for revisions to be submitted within a deadline of 90 days for approval or disapproval of the revision. After approval of a management plan, the management entity must periodically review and submit recommendations for any revisions to the Secretary for approval. No funds can be used to implement a revision until approved by the Secretary. The Secretary may provide technical and financial assistance to the heritage area for developing and implementing the management plan, prioritizing conservation and educational opportunities. This assistance is given priority to actions that facilitate the conservation of natural, cultural, historical, scenic, and recreational resources supporting the heritage area's purposes. The Act ensures that occupational, safety, conservation, and environmental regulations for the heritage area are not more stringent than existing regulations. It also clarifies that land use regulations do not grant zoning powers to the management entity. SEC. 8. REQUIREMENTS FOR INCLUSION OF PRIVATE PROPERTY.

(a) Notification and Consent of Property Owners Required--Privately owned property in the Heritage Area must receive written notification and consent from the owner for preservation, conservation, or promotion by the management entity.
(b) Landowner Withdrawal--Owners can request immediate removal of their private property from the Heritage Area boundary.

SEC. 9. PRIVATE PROPERTY PROTECTION. The Act ensures that private property owners are not required to allow public access or modify laws regarding access. It also states that designation as a Heritage Area does not create liability for property owners. The Act does not affect government authority to regulate land use or require property owners to participate in the Heritage Area. The boundaries represent the area eligible for federal funds. The Heritage Area designation does not grant regulatory authority over land use or require private property owners to participate. Federal funds can only be expended within the designated boundaries. SEC. 10. Authorization of Appropriations: $10,000,000 authorized for this Act, with $1,000,000 limit per fiscal year. Federal share not to exceed 50%.

SEC. 11. Termination of Authority: Secretary's grant and assistance authority ends on September 30, 2016.
